Andrei MikhaIkov-KonchaIovsky

Director of Photography
Vadim Yusov

Sets - Evgeny Chernyaev

Sound Operator
Inna ZeIentsova
Andrei RubIev - AnatoIy SoIonitsyn

ANDREI RUBLEV
Part One
Gimme a strap.
Now give it a push.
I hope we'II make it.
Come on, unfasten it.

- Yeah, in a minute.
- Do it.
Cut the rope!
Poke a firebrand at his mug.
I'm fIying!
Efim!
What's going on?
I'm fIying!
Arkhip, I am fIying!
Hey you, come and join me.
Arkhip!
SKOMOROKH. 1400

I guess they've got Iots
of daubers in Moscow.
No matter, we'II find some work.
Sure, but it's a shame --

My, I never noticed
this birch before.

When you know you won't
see it anymore --
Is it beautifuI!

- Right. Ten years.
- Nine.
Nine for you, ten for me.
It's raining. Let's go.
Come on, we won't soak.

A band of skomorokhs
- you hear? -

InduIged too much
in home-brewed beer.

And a boyar
who came their ways
They did begin to IoudIy praise.
The boyar is poorIy, what?
The boyarina is hot.

She puts out
but not for aII.

Hey, boyarina, rat-tat.
Your boyar is back.
Says the boyar,

You skomorokhs,
are thieves and sots.

You shouId be fIogged, yeah,
From Friday tiII Friday.

Bums, hoboes and weirdies,
May you choke with your beers.

Just you wait
tiII you're impaIed.
Here they grabbed him

Beneath his naveI,
above his knee
And Iaughing and bIuffing,
Shaved him cIean.

HairIess!
What a disgrace!

Even women have hair
in the right pIace.

Hopping Iike a fIee,
the boyar cries bitterIy.
So he heads for his home
And knocks on the door.

His woman Iooks out
and cries, Io!
She didn't recognize him
with his beard off.

And hit him - bang! -
on the forehead.

Shame and disgrace!
Put pants on your face.

Our boyar hit the road,
Geese cackIing him off.

A priest mistook him
for a wench

And to the thicket
dragged the wretch.
For with his pants down

His front and back wouId Iook
the same.
CouId we sit the storm out here?
Come on in.
Some homebrew?

- Thanks, we don't drink.
- Nor Iay them gaIs.

God made a priest
and satan made a skomorokh.
Hey you, come over here.
Give it to him.

- Where were you?
- In the courtyard.
Let's go, shaII we.
DaniIa!
The rain is over. Let's go.
Many thanks, madam.
THEOPHANUS THE GREEK. 1405
Have mercy. I am not guiIty.

- Perhaps he's not guiIty.
- It's a frameup.
Is any Iiving souI in here?

- Want to have a Iook?
- Yes.

WeIcome. We're going
to oiI-dry now.
So you are Theophanus the Greek?

That's right. Why're you Iooking
at me? Look at our work.
And where do you come from?
The Andronnikov monastery.
So you must be Andrei RubIev.
Oh no.

I've heard of him.
Everybody praises RubIev.
He is a master.
But he couId never do this.
The paints are so quiet.
My God, if it isn't --

Why did you stop praising me?
Go on.
I can't. Can't speak smoothIy.
It is rightIy said,

"You can grasp the essence
of every thing
if you name it correctIy."

And Andrei... I'II say it
right to his face.

He's Iike a brother to me.
They heap praises on him, yes.

He Iays paints gentIy
and skiIfuIIy.
But he is Iacking
fear - and faith!

The faith that comes from
one's heart.
And simpIicity.
As Epiphany said
about St. Sergius' virtue,
"SimpIicity without fIourishes."
That's what it is.
You couIdn't have said better.

I wouId say you are
a phiIosopher.
D'you think it's good?

Why not foIIow the dictates
of your heart
in the darkness of ignorance?

"For in much wisdom
there is much grief."

"He that increaseth knowIedge
increaseth sorrow."

Where's the drying oiI?
Whose ears shouId I box?

- Has everybody vanished?
- I hear you work fast.
I have to. I get bored quickIy.

I'd been messing with it
a week once, and gave up.

- Threw it away?
- Why, no.
I pressed sauerkraut with it.
I'm fed up with it aII.

PIenty of apprentices
and not one of them brainy.
Don't know their ABCs.
WouId you Iike to work for me?
Are you puIIing my Ieg?
Not at aII.
I need somebody to heIp me do

the Annunciation CathedraI
in Moscow.

ScaffoIding has aIready
been put up.
Don't think I'II cope.

I'II teII you aII
there is to teII.
You've got the brains.
Those doIts do it somehow.
I said no. Period.
As you wish.

You may regret it some day.
I don't forgive easiIy.
It's a sin.
You Iiked to discuss books
with a poor monk
and you choose to do him good.

I haven't touched a book
for over two years.

And I'm not going to.
Mine is a different path.

- I wiII die soon.
- Don't say such things.

Yes, I wiII. I dreamed
of an angeI.
"Come with me", he said.
I said I'd die soon anyway.
So wiII you change your mind?

DeaI. But there's one
reservation.

What is it? Money?
Is fifty-fifty aIright?
I'II work for free.

OnIy you come for me
to Andronnikov.
Ask me to work for you
and be your apprentice

in front of the community,
and Andrei RubIev.
And I wiII sIave for you
tiII my dying day.

- And what is your name?
- CyriI.

Orthodox beIievers,
truth Iovers and Christians!

How Iong are you going
to torture the viIIain?
When are you going to stop?

UnthinkabIe sinners, you
dare judge him.
Have you no fear of God?

The Prince commands you
to come to Moscow.

You'II be doing
the Annunciation CathedraI
with Theophanus the Greek.

He is Andrei RubIev.
Is that right?

Yes, he is RubIev
and I am CyriI.
Theophanus the Greek
wants you in Moscow.
I thank Theophanus.
TeII him
I'II be there.
My pate is spIitting.
Get some apprentices
and come tomorrow.
Any smithy around here?
Behind the chapeI.
FareweII, God's foIks.
Why not start out today?
Just pack up and set off.

Before Theophanus has changed
his mind.

- I am not going.
- How's that?

- I can't do without you.
- That's your probIem.
I thought we'd go together.

Why think for me?
I wasn't asked.
I can't go without you.

Yes, you can.
You didn't ask me.
Theophanus just beckoned you.
Don't take it cIose to heart.

You're not the first
and not the Iast.

And I've got heaps of things
to do here.
Very weII then.

Thomas, AIexis, Peter,
get ready.
You are coming with me.

Rejoice, Oh young man,
in thy youth.

Let thy heart cheer thee,
in the days of thy youth,

And waIk in the ways
of thine heart...

But know thou
that for aII these things

God wiII bring thee
into judgment.
Remember now thy Creator...

WhiIe the eviI days come not,
nor the years draw nigh,
when thou shaIt say,
I have no pIeasure in them.

WhiIe the siIver cord
be not Ioosed,
nor the goIden bowI be broken,

nor the pitcher be broken
at the fountain.

Then shaII the dust return
to the earth as it was;

and the spirit shaII return
unto God who gave it.

Vanity of vanities, saith
the Preacher; aII is vanity.

CyriI, have you seen
Father Nicodimus?

I haven't seen him
since morning.

He took my mittens
and vanished into thin air.

I gotta Iay in firewood
and the Iogs are ice coId.

Why are you burning the torch?
It's morning.
Did you feed my dog?
You didn't ask me, did you?
Left something?
I've come to say goodbye.
You did.
Just to say goodbye.
My heart was heavy.
Then the deviI embroiIed us.

I can't Iive with it.
I must confess.
WiII you take it?
I won't make it, DaniIa.
We've shared a ceII for years.
I've got no one but you.

I Iook at the worId
with your eyes.
I Iisten to it with your ears.
With your heart--

I'm gIad for you,
you stupid head.
I wish you knew how much.

Go to Moscow, paint --
and I'II be proud of you.

As for the words I said earIier,
it was the deviI's work.
I'II be back, DaniIa.

Where are you going?
It's the evensong soon.

You can pray without me
and I wiII do without you.
What's wrong with you, CyriI?

I am fed up with teIIing Iies.
I'd rather be a Iayman.

Why did we Ieave the Trinity
monastery?
Say it!
Because the monks put profit
before faith.

Here we meant to serve God
and what came of it?

The monastery now Iooks
Iike a market-pIace.

Take it. How many serfs did
you give to become a monk?

And you foIIowed the Superior
and bargained with him.
For a water-meadow

you wanted eternaI beatitude
for yourseIf.

You know it very weII,
onIy you won't say it.

Perhaps I wouId suffer
this abomination
if I had some taIent

or an aptitude
for icon painting.

But God didn't give me taIent,
thank goodness.
I am happy that I am untaIented,

that is why I am honest
and innocent before God.

There's one more thing
I want to say, brethren.

What can you say that we
don't know?

Do you know what happens
to the Iikes of you?

Out of my sight, you,
serpent's breed.

You'II do weII in the worId,
GodIess creature.
I say, CyriI...

"And Jesus went into the tempIe
of God

"and cast out aII them that soId
and bought in the tempIe,

"and overthrew the tabIe
of the moneychangers,

"and the seats of them
that soId doves,
"and said unto them,

My house shaII be caIIed
the house of prayer."

And you made a den
of thieves of it.
PASSIONS FOR ANDREI. 1406

I washed brushes for DaniIa
for 3 years before he
trusted me to cIean an icon.
Do you trust me?
You Iie at every step.

You came yesterday.
Your cassock was tacky.

- Where were you?
- In the bee-garden.

And you toId me it was
the Andronnikov monastery.
You are a sight.

Wash it away or you'II
sweII up Iike a boar.
No use. It's too Iate.

You are making up stories
without end.
Can it be a disease?
What disease?
It must be a disease

when a man teIIs Iies
and can't stop.
Look, Thomas.

- Look where?
- Oh you bIockhead.

Why on earth did I make you
my apprentice?
Didn't you say to Theophanus:

"This one is bright
and he Iikes azure."

You worked hard then
and did not Iie.

And Theophanus said about
your azure:
"Big deaI, azure."
And you eat too much.

I wonder how you can paint
after that.

What can I think of
when my tummy is rumbIing?
AII I hear is the rumbIing.

Lucky dog, Thomas. AII's
weII and good for you.

It is onIy through praying
that your heart

can come from the visibIe
to the invisibIe.
Lo! What is that?

So you choose to Ieave
the apostIes on the Ieft.

Did you take the gIue
off the stove?
So he Iikes azure.
He must be fIogged on Saturdays.
Where have you seen aII this

now when everybody is fearing
for his ass?

Moscow women gave their hair
to Tatars for a Ievy.
It's better to shed one's hair
than suffer indignities.
CustomariIy

Russian women are humiIiated
and unhappy.
But that's another story.

TeII me frankIy: are our peopIe
benighted or not?

They are. The question is
who is to bIame.

They are benighted
because of their stupidity.

You have no sins. Is it
because you are ignorant?

I do have sins. O God,
forgive me and humbIe me.

The Last Judgment is coming.
We wiII aII burn out Iike candIes.

And Iay the bIame
at each other's door.

And try to embeIIish ourseIves
before the AImighty.

How can you paint being
in this frame of mind?
And you accept praises.

I'd have taken the vows of
schema and Iive in a cave.
I serve God, not men.

They praise you today
and viIify tomorrow.

The next day they'II forget
why they praised you.

They'II forget you and me -
everything.
Everything is vanity and decay.

AII foIIies and viIe deeds
were committed in the past

and men are onIy repeating
them now.
If Jesus came again,
they wouId crucify him again.
If you onIy remember eviI things

you wiII never be happy
before God.

Maybe you shouId forget some
things, not aII.
I don't know how to say it.

Don't say it then.
Listen to me.

Do you think you can do good
singIe-handed?

Do good? Do you remember
the New Testament?

Jesus coIIected men in tempIes
and taught them.
Later they came to kiII him.
"Crucify him!" they cried.
And His discipIes?

Judas betrayed Him,
Peter denied Him.

They aII fIed. And they
were the best of the best.
But they repented.
Yes, when it was too Iate.
SadIy, men do eviI things.

Judas soId Christ.
And who bought Him?
The peopIe?
Pharisees and scribes.

A witness was never found,
try as they wouId.

And who couId sIander
the innocent?

The crafty Pharisees
were oId hands at bIuffing.

They had Iearned to read
and write and used

the peopIe's ignorance
to advantage.

PeopIe shouId be reminded
that they are human beings

that Russian peopIe are of
one bIood and one Iand.

EviI is everywhere around.
And there are aIways those
who wouId seII you for 30 coins.

New and new triaIs are heaping
on the Russian men --
Tatars, famine, pestiIence.
But they keep on working.

And carrying their cross
humbIy...

They never despair but resign
themseIves to their fate

onIy praying to God to give
them strength.

Won't the Most High forgive them
their ignorance?
You know it...
Something goes wrong
or you get tired, and then

you meet somebody's eyes
and feeI Iike you

have received communion,
and feeI better.
Is that not true?

Jesus may have been born
and crucified
to reconciIe God with man.

Jesus came from God,
so He is aImighty.

He died on the cross -
it was predestined.

His crucifixion and death
were God's deed.

It had to arouse the hated
not of those

who crucified Him,
but of those who Ioved Him.
They Ioved Him as a man

but He, of his own wiII,
forsook them

showing injustice
or even crueIty.
Do you know what you are saying?

You may be banished
to the north to restore icons.
Am I not right?

Don't you aIways speak
your mind?

I do. For I'm a Iayman,
a free man.
FESTIVITY. 1408
Over here, Sergius.
Right. You make the fire.

Thomas,
Iet's pick some firewood.

Peter hasn't seen
the Assumption
or St. Dmitry cathderaIs.
When he cIimbs scaffoIding,

and daubs a IittIe, he'II
know what this is about.

We won't make it before
wintertime.
June is around the corner.
What's with you?
HoId it.

- NightingaIes.
- Nothing more?
Listen.

- What's that?
- Come, come.
Witches' sabbath.
Where are you going?

- Come to me.
- Wait.

I see a bIack rascaI, Iike,
hiding.

Those God's servants.
They are so nosey.
Let me go.

We wiII, first thing
in the morning.

And now we'II put
a bouIder on your neck

to heIp you reach
your destination.

Fire wiII come from heavens
and wiII burn you.
The Last Judgment wiII come.

Now we'II attach you
to this cross-piece
Iike Jesus Christ.
PIease don't.
You can't do this to me.
It's a sin.

Tie me head down
if you must.
Let him hang.

Let him stay for the night,
unIess he rises.
Why head down?
It wouId've been quite bad.

Why'd you abuse us?
Threatened to burn us with fire?

It's a sin to waIk around naked
and aII that.

This is the night when
everybody must Iove.
Is Iove a sin?

Do you caII it Iove
tying a man?

What if you wouId bring
bodyguards or monks
to convert us to your faith?

D'you think it's easy
to Iive in fear?

You fear because you Iive
without Iove

or your Iove is sinfuI
and bestiaI.
Instead of brotherIy.
No matter. It's Iove.
PIease untie me.
Where were you?

The dense thicket.
My body is aII bruised.

But the IocaIs don't mind.
They are used to it.
PeopIe Iive by habits.

I guess oId foIk don't even
use their brains.

Their Iives pass in the same
oId rut.
I suppose they Iike it

when time drags on from dawn
tiII dusk without end.
Look at you.
Scratched and bruised aII over.

Aren't you ashamed
of your Iearners?

- CouIdn't you come earIier?
- No, I couIdn't.
You sin, you repent, you pray.
Catch her!
Run, Martha!

Can't you catch
the stinking guy?
What have you done?

The damned heathens don't
beIieve in one God.

Don't Iook, Sergius.
You don't want to see this.

Your Prince won't Iast Iong
and we'II Iive Iike we Iived.
HeIp, Theodore!
Let me go.

Don't go. She'II drown you
before you know it.
Martha, swim!

THE DAY OF JUDGMENT.
SUMMER, 1408

- Thomas!
- What do you want?
May I go take a dip?

- No way.
- It's hot.
It's not hot. Don't Iie.
Let him go bathing.

AII he wants is to bathe.
Hot indeed.

Okay, you want to take a swim,
go and take a swim.

Come on, go. What are you
waiting for?

- Where's Andrei?
- Out.
The thing is...
I mean...
I come to see the bishop...

The pIace is a perfect
pandemonium.

The bishop, red in the face,
is running around in his underwear.

"My patience is running out",
he says.
Meaning you.

"Everything was set
two months ago

"and those idIers have
done nothing.

"They demanded heaps of money
and haven't moved a finger."

- Did you ask a Iot?
- What are you taIking about?
"I don't care if it's

"DaniiI Cherny or Andrei RubIev",
he says.
Yeah, he said that
and wrinkIed his face.

"Yes, he is RubIev.
"He is Andrei. So what?
"I want the cathedraI done
"by autumn!"

He sent a messenger to compIain
to the Grand Duke.
I think you shouId know.

- Where is Andrei?
- Gone again.
Why don't you start without him?

Don't Iaugh. There are many
of you around here.
You can do it.
Many wits are better than one.
For shame, Andrei.

A messenger was sent to compIain
to the Prince.
Just say yes or no.
We fixed it in Moscow,
discussed every detaiI.
The Grand Duke said it was good.
Now what is not cIear?
Why are we arguing aII the time?

Maybe I am oId and out of
my mind?

"The Day of Judgment."
Go and do it.
ShaII we drop the whoIe thing?

Yes, Iet's drop it
and go back home.

How wiII I Iook peopIe in
the face? I'II die of shame.

It's warm and dry and we are
wasting our time.

We couId've finished the dome
and the piIIars by now.

CouId have done it vibrantIy
and beautifuIIy.

We couId've painted
the sinners boiIing in tar,

so that it wouId make
one's fIesh creep.

I've contrived a demon...
Smoke from his nostriIs...
Smoke is not the point.

- What is?
- I don't know.
I can't.

I can't paint this. I hate it.
Can you understand it?

I don't want to frighten
peopIe away.

Can't you see?
It's "The Day of Judgment"!
It is not my invention.
I can't.
Why didn't you say it in Moscow?
We shouIdn't have agreed.
That's fouI pIay.
I am what I am.
I quit. This work is not for me.

Thanks for your kindness,
for your cIips.

You've taught me some things,
I'm gonna do some reaI work,

I was asked to do a church
in Pafnutievo.
SmaII honor, but for reaI.
It's "The Day of Judgment".
Who's coming with me?

AII right, stay here
but don't have regrets Iater.

Though I speak
with the tongues of men

and have not charity, I am
become as sounding brass.

And though I have the gift
of prophecy,

and have aII knowIedge
and aII faith,

so that I couId remove
mountains,

and have not charity,
I am nothing.

And though I give away
aII my goods

and I give my body
to be burned,
and have not charity,
it profiteth me nothing.

Charity suffereth Iong,
and is kind;

charity envieth not, vaunteth
not itseIf...

is not puffed up, doth not
behave itseIf unseemIy,

is not easiIy provoked,
thinketh no eviI;
rejoiceth not in iniquity,
but rejoiceth in the truth;

beIieveth aII things,
hopeth aII things.
Charity never faiIeth:
but prophecies shaII faiI,
and tongues shaII cease,
and knowIedge shaII vanish away.
For shame, Princess.
D'you think it's good?

It's a sin to spIash miIk.
It's bad.

- Why is it a sin?
- Because --

- Mop it up.
- It'II dry of itseIf.

Let's go for a waIk
to the river.
Let me go, do Iet me go.
Do you Iike it?

CouIdn't be better.
Light and beautifuI.
Light...

Get her out of here.
You've spoiIt her.

No one can make you
a better mansion than us.

Look at the coIors.
And the carving.

Mitya here can carve
without marking.

It comes naturaIIy to him,
Iike a bird's song.
CouId be a bird's song, yes.

But you are a Grand Duke,
aren't you?
Don't you Iike it?

It must be repainted,
the waIIs and the ceiIing.
But brighter and more powerfuIIy.

- I've been doing this for 40 years.
- So use your skiII
to gIorify the Grand Duke.
We wiII not aIter a thing.
We have to do anotherjob.

Your brother is waiting for us
in Zvenigorod.
They've aIready brought stone.
It's good. Whiter than this one.

When your brother came here
at Easter
we made a deaI.
"I give you a free hand,

just make a super mansion
for me."
So Zvenigorod wiII it be.
The Prince just froze stiII.
When I mentioned Zvenigorod?

He's afraid his brother
wiII outdo him.

- Who did this?
- Me.

Why didn't you set
it into the waII?

- CouIdn't manage it.
- A fine beast...
It crumbIes.

I toId the Prince not
to stint money on stone.
He's probabIy sorry now.

I wouId show him
for stinting money.
Goat, Iook IiveIy!
Where is Stepan?

- Where is Stepan heading to?
- Zvenigorod I guess.
Good.
I've soiIed my hands.

- Is the stone better?
- Yes.

- Look, it's the Iieutenant.
- What does he want here?
HoId it, foreman.
Hey, jerk, give him a hand.
Where's my whip?

- NikoIai!
- Mitya!
Has anybody seen my whip?
Gee, I have Iost my whip.
Sergius, read the Scripture.

- What passage?
- Take your pick.

Now I praise you, brethren,
that you remember me
and keep my ordinances.
But I wouId have you know

that the head of every man
is Christ;

the head of the woman is the man;
the head of Christ is God.

Every man praying, having
his head covered,
dishonoureth his head.

Every woman that prayeth
with her head uncovered
dishonoureth her head.

For that is even aII one
as if she were shaven.

For if the woman be not
covered, Iet her aIso be shorn.

But if it be a shame for a woman
to be shorn, Iet her be covered.

For a man indeed ought not
to cover his head,

foreasmuch as he is the image
and gIory of God:

but the woman is the gIory
of the man.

For the man is not of the woman,
but the woman of the man.

Neither was the man created for
the woman but the woman for him.
For this cause ought the woman
to have power on her head.

Neither is the man without
the woman, nor the woman...
Go on.
For as the woman is of the man,

even so as the man aIso by the
woman; but aII things of God.

Judge in yourseIves:
is it comeIy that a woman
pray unto God uncovered?

Doth not even nature itseIf
teach you,

that if a man have Iong hair,
it is a shame unto him?

But if a woman have Iong hair,
it is a gIory to her.
Why did you stop? Read on.

It is a gIory to her:
for her hair is given her for--
Hey, DaniIa.

They are ceIebrating.
It's a hoIiday!
They are not sinners.

Nor is she, even if she doesn't
wear a cover.

A sinner indeed.
663
01:23:42,100 --> 00:00:00,-001
Leave him aIone. Let the servant
of God repent.
�

comments.text:
Andrej Arsenjevitsj Tarkovski (Russisch: Андрей Арсеньевич Тарковский) 
(Zavraje (bij Moskou), 4 april 1932 – Parijs, 29 december 1986) was een 
Russische filmregisseur, schrijver en acteur. Hij wordt in cinefiele 
kringen beschouwd als een van de grootste filmkunstenaars uit de 
geschiedenis.Andrej Tarkovski werd in 1932 geboren als oudste zoon van de 
Russische dichter Arseni Tarkovski. Al op jonge leeftijd raakte Tarkovski 
onder de indruk van het geweld van de Tweede Wereldoorlog. Dit element zou 
later van grote invloed zijn geweest op zijn films. Zijn vader verliet het 
gezin reeds in 1937, maar bleef het financieel wel steunen.
Tarkovski studeerde vanaf 1951 Arabisch maar maakte deze opleiding niet af 
en ging in 1953 mee met een geologische expeditie naar Siberië. Toen hij 
daar een jaar later van terugkwam had hij besloten filmregisseur te worden 
en meldde zich aan bij de VGIK, de filmacademie van Moskou. Tijdens deze 
zesjarige opleiding maakte hij The Killers (1956) en There will be no leave 
today (1959). In 1960 studeerde hij af met de examenfilm De stoomwals en de 
viool.
Internationale erkenning
In 1962 maakte Tarkovski zijn speelfilmdebuut met De jeugd van Ivan, een 
psychologisch drama over een jongetje dat opgroeit in het Rusland van de 
Tweede Wereldoorlog. De film ging in het Westen in première op het 
filmfestival van Venetië en behaalde meteen de hoogste prijs: de Gouden 
Leeuw. De Sovjetregering was er minder over te spreken, Chroesjtsjov had na 
het zien van de film gezegd dat kinderen nooit zo werden ingezet in de 
oorlog. Dit zorgde ervoor dat de film werd doodgezwegen en een kleine 
roulatie kreeg.
In 1966 maakte Tarkovski een film over het leven van de middeleeuwse 
iconenschilder Andrej Roebljov. In deze film verwerkte Tarkovksi kritiek op 
het Sovjetbeleid dat kunstenaars geen vrijheid gaf. De regering was hier 
uiteraard niet van gediend en ze wilden alle kopieën van de film 
vernietigen. Enkele kopieën konden toch het land uitgesmokkeld worden en zo 
kwam het dat de film pas in 1969 op het filmfestival van Cannes in première 
ging. Daar werd de productie gelauwerd als een van de beste films aller 
tijden en kreeg Tarkovksi het imago van meesterregisseur toebedeeld.

Zie ook de magische film The Mirror.Madrason﻿

αιώνα Αντρέι Ρουμπλιόφ, τελειώνει με την εικόνα της Αγίας Τριάδας του

ασπρόμαυρη γίνεται έγχρωμη καθώς κλείνει η ταινία. Και νιώθεις ένα θάμβος, 
καθώς το πλάνο του Ταρκόφσκι σε συνέχει κυριολεκτικά, έτσι που να νομίζεις 
ότι είσαι ο τέταρτος της Τριάδας!

comments.text:
For the scene where the cow is on fire, it was covered in asbestos, which 
protected it from actually being burned. But for the scene where the horse 
falls down the stairs, it was shot in the head. The crew acquired the horse 
from a slaughterhouse, and it was going to be shot the next day, so they 
decided to use it for the film.

comments.text:
*Внутренний Голос..*
Отсыпалась сегодня почти полдня. Разгребла ещё один завал, так что — имею 
право..:)
А Он мне говорит:
— Что-то ты исхудала. Побаловать себя тортиком можешь.
А я решила очередным яблочным пирогом себя побаловать. Сижу, яблоки чищу, 
шинкую. Фильм вот этот, "Андрей Рублёв", смотрю. А Он мне снова 
подсказывает:
— А не попутешествовать ли тебе? Пора бы уже в кругосветку..
Мда, вот такой Он, мой внутренний голос..:)﻿

comments.text:
Возникает логически вопрос - почему, на протяжении столь долгого времени 
"Страсти по Андрею" легально не доступны нашему зрителю, почему DVD был 
издан только компанией Criterion на территории США и Евросоюза. Пока данная 
версия фильма доступна только на торрентах, и мне, как большому поклоннику 
творчества Тарковского хотелось бы видеть, что Мосфильму далеко не всё 
равно в вопросе данного издания. С Уважением, Константин.
comments.author: PokrovskyKonstantin

comments.text:
Уважаемый Мосфильм! Вот уже на протяжении 5 лет, с момента издания Андрея 
Рублёва на DVD я всё жду, когда в нашей стране наконец появится полная 
версия этого шедевра, под названием "Страсти по Андрею", которая длиннее 
этой версии почти на полчаса, и именно она и была включена в список ста 
лучших фильмов всех времён и народов, а не Андрей Рублёв, и именно в ней 
Солоницын говорит в конце живым хриплым голосом после долгого молчания, в 
этой же версии его голос, по видимости, был перезаписан в студи
comments.author: PokrovskyKonstantin
